title.narrative: Collaborating, Influencing, and Learning: Civil Society and Research for Development - A Canadian Perspective
Collaborer, influencer et apprendre : la société civile et la recherche au service du développement - un point de vue canadien

description.narrative: IDRC research awardees have helped shed light on the many challenges Canadian civil society organizations face, and the practices they have implemented to overcome them when collaborating on research for development. This project will allow the Canadian Partnerships program to condense and update these studies, conducted between 2006-2014, for publication in book form. Canadian perspective on research for development Canadian civil society organizations (CSOs) have drawn a number of lessons and developed new approaches to working with developing-country researchers, CSOs, institutions, governments, and policymakers: -when collaborating in research and knowledge-oriented activities for development -when using research to influence policies and practices -when learning from their experience to improve. The changing international cooperation scene The political and economic environment in which CSOs engage in international cooperation and development work has changed radically in recent years. There is growing pressure for them to do more with less, and they need to re-define their niche in the international development community. This is especially important given the emergence or re-emergence of other actors: -global South diaspora in higher income countries -corporations based in developed countries and in emerging economy countries -private sector funded foundations -more sophisticated CSOs in developing countries. Competition for funds Increasingly, CSOs working internationally compete with one another for dedicated public funding envelopes. They also compete with other types of organizations that are now permitted to compete for the funds. CSOs are learning to collaborate, if not partner, with new actors. Understanding the Canadian experience Although these issues have been the subject of international conferences, particularly in Europe, there is little systematic research available on the Canadian experience so far. IDRC funded researchers have explored: -the political economy of research agenda setting in collaboration situations between developing and developed country partners; -CSO strategies in low-income countries to access knowledge and expertise; -Canadian CSO strategies used in working overseas to influence changes in practice and policy through research; -the tensions involved in research collaboration between development-oriented Canadian CSOs and academic institutions; and -the challenges CSOs face, and the inspiring practices some have developed, to improve their organizations. This resulting book will synthesize these studies in one publication intended for civil society organizations, development practitioners, scholars, and universities.
